--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
> Parameterize=
d is designed to work with datasets that are expensive to
> navigate, like =
filesystem folders or database tables or huge XML
> files.  A JUnit design =
rule is that all the tests have to be named
> before any of them is run, an=
d naming should not be an expensive
> activity.

Hm, good point. My use in =
this particular case was a search in which
any of 6 optional parameters may=
 be sent in, so I thought to use
parameterized to test the various combinat=
ions of empty and non-empty
search parameters (i.e. "sent name only", "sent=
 city and state only"
etc.). 

I even made factories to represent the expec=
ted values from the
database and set that as the last ("expected") value fo=
r each parameter.

So it was a small set computationally but large enough t=
hat I thought
it would increase readability and usability using parameteriz=
ed. 

Perhaps there was a better way to do it.

Gabriel.
